title: Wakatipu High School student Meg Jolly wins top scholarship award
text:
Wakatipu High School student Meg Jolly wins top scholarship award DEBBIE JAMIESON Last updated 16:47, February 14 2017 Debbie Jamieson 
Wakatipu High School student Meg Jolly was the top photography student in the Year 13 Scholarships in New Zealand last year. 
A Wakatipu High School student has achieved the top scholarship mark in New Zealand in photography with a perfect score for her portfolio. 
Meg Jolly, 18, said she couldn't believe it when she realised she was the nation's top scholar and received a 24/24 mark. 
"It was crazy...and so humbling that someone got my panel and understood the ideas and liked it." Meg Jolly 
This image represents the gifts of women including the ability to create life. 
Her portfolio was concerned with female empowerment and historical perceptions of women and included a lot of pink, a colour traditionally associated with women. 
"I used that as an empowering thing. Pink can be a strong colour and women are strong." 
It was edgy with fruit symbolising women's fertility, a lightly clad female posterior and one image of "the naughty finger" but Jolly still shared it with her grandmother. Meg Jolly 
A photo representing the feminisation of an object associated with aggression and masculine power. 
"I like it Meg. I think the photos are interesting...." was her grandmother's response. 
It is also optimistic. 
"We are coming into an age where women are powerful and have a new voice," Meg explained. Meg Jolly 
This image represents self love for women and de-sexualizing the female body. 
This year Meg is studying communications at Massey University with a plan to combine her interest and abilities in design work with journalism and marketing. She intends picking up photography as an elective subject in her second year. Ad Feedback 
The $2000 a year toward her future study was appreciated and would look good on her resume for may years to come. 
Wakatipu High School principal Steve Hall said it may be the first time the school has had a nationwide top scholar in the year 13 scholarship programme. Debbie Jamieson 
Photography work by Wakatipu High School student Meg Jolly, which saw here awarded New Zealand's top photography student. 
In addition to Meg's outstanding scholarship the school received another 11 scholarships. 
Elysia Harcombe achieved scholarships in statistics, English, Biology and an outstanding scholarship in geography. 
Esmond Paterson also received an outstanding scholarship, in Drama. 
Scholarships were also awarded to Hamish Attenborough (Calculus), Ella Buchanan (Drama), Lily Gamson (Drama), Rosie Glanfield (Statistics), Ashley Kirkness-Burney (Technology) and Anna Moore (History). 
While most scholarship students were in Year 13, Hamish was in Year 11 and Esmond and Lily were Year 12. Additionally Sophie Aitken, who attended Wakatipu High School for three years before going to Mt Albert Grammar School last year and returning to Queenstown this year achieved a scholarship in Physical Education last year at Mt Albert Grammar as a Year 12 student. - Stuff
